CALL FOR PAPERS:
JOURNAL OF THE ASSOCIATION FOR SOFTWARE TESTING

The Jour=
nal of the Association for Software Testing ( 
http://associationforsoftwar=
etesting.org/) is seeking papers on the 
theory, practice, and teaching of =
software testing for its first 
issues. We welcome papers from scholars and=
 from practitioners in the 
field. We will also consider proposals for spec=
ial issues organized by 
a guest editor.

We welcome submissions at any tim=
e, but our tentative deadline for 
articles for the first issue is Septembe=
r 1, 2005.

The emphasis of the first issue will be on putting the field in=
 
perspective. There are some very strongly different visions of testing. 
=
A broad paper that gives the reader insight into one of those visions 
(alo=
ng with supporting empirical data or literature review) would be 
particula=
rly welcome. Well-researched and well-documented attacks on 
other viewpoin=
ts are as welcome as well-researched and well-documented 
advocations.

Sub=
missions outside of this emphasis will still be considered, but 
might be p=
ublished in the next issue.

The Charter for the Journal is at the end of t=
his message, as is a list 
of members of our Editorial Board. The Charter d=
escribes in more detail 
the types of papers that we will consider.

To sub=
mit a paper, please send the manuscript to Cem Kaner, 
kaner@....

Au=
thors are encouraged to submit abstracts before writing and sending 
papers=
. The abstract can be any reasonable length. Abstracts will be 
rapidly eva=
luated, not peer reviewed. The response to the abstract will 
be brief, of =
the nature "Yes, this appears to be within the scope of 
the Journal and co=
uld be a promising paper" or "No, we are not likely 
to accept a paper alon=
g these lines." A positive response to an 
abstract will not be a commitmen=
t to publish the associated paper, nor 
is a negative response a guaranteed=
 rejection  of the associated paper. 
It is merely a rough, informal indica=
tor that might save some 
prospective authors some time.

We expect to publ=
ish the Journal on the Web, under a Creative Commons 
license that allows a=
nyone to reprint the article but not to modify it. 
Articles will be format=
ted consistently, paginated consecutively across 
issues, within an annual =
volume. It will *look* like a traditional 
printed journal, but it will be =
available to the testing community for 
free. We follow the style of the Am=
erican Psychological Association 
(http://www.apastyle.org/) largely becaus=
e this is the most carefully 
defined and most accessible professional soci=
ety style available to 
prospective authors.

AST is a recently-formed nonp=
rofit professional service organization 
dedicated to advancing the underst=
anding and practice of software 
testing.=A0The AST serves a community of s=
cholars, students, and software 
development practitioners by providing for=
ums for discussion of all 
aspects of software testing through conferences,=
 publications, web 
sites, and other services.

EDITORIAL CHARTER OF THE
JOURNAL OF THE ASSOCIATION FOR SOFTWARE TES=
TING

The primary purpose of the Journal of the Association for Software 
T=
esting is to publish peer-reviewed materials of archival value that 
advanc=
e the understanding and practice of software testing. The Journal 
will acc=
ept a wide range of original, unpublished materials.

JAST is published ele=
ctronically rather than in print. As a result, 
printing costs do not const=
rain the length of articles. Articles can be 
of any length, but must be co=
ncisely written; verbose articles will be 
returned to the author for revis=
ion.

EMPIRICAL & THEORETICAL RESEARCH (Peer Reviewed)

JAST welcomes origi=
nal scientific and engineering research reports. 
Papers that focus on a ma=
thematical model are welcome; however our 
strong preference is that such a=
 paper include data that at least 
establishes the plausibility of the mode=
l.

Model journals for articles in this category

=95 	ACM Transactions on =
Software Engineering=A0and Methodology
=95 	IEEE Transactions on Software E=
ngineering
=95 	Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory & Cogn=
ition
=95 	Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
=95 	Perception & P=
sychophysics

We encourage authors to include appendices that provide fine =
details of 
experimental methods or a finer-grained presentation of the 
ex=
perimental data.

LITERATURE REVIEWS (Peer Reviewed)

A literature review i=
s a thorough guided tour through the published 
material related to a speci=
fic question or topic. The author of the 
review helps the reader make sens=
e of the topic under discussion, its 
literature, and the controversies in =
the literature. A review may be 
written at the level of a tutorial (for pe=
ople who are somewhat 
knowledgeable about testing in general but not about=
 this topic in 
particular) or at a level that assumes a professional under=
standing of 
the field. A tutorial-level paper should be appropriate as a 
=
required-reading assignment in an undergraduate course on software 
testing=
. A professional-level paper should be appropriate for use in a 
graduate c=
ourse on software testing.

Within this category, we will also consider ref=
lections. A reflection 
is a narrowly-scoped review that puts years of the =
author's work in 
perspective. For example, the head of a research laborato=
ry might 
describe the evolution and progress of her research program, its =

successes, surprises and problems. A consultant might describe the 
evolut=
ion of his practice. A manager of a corporate test group that 
consciously =
innovates might describe the evolution of the group's 
practice. A reflecti=
on must connect the described work to the scholarly 
and/or practitioners' =
publications that guided or reported the work, 
and to additional publicati=
ons that will place the work in context for 
the reader.

Literature review=
 authors are welcome to build a case for a theoretical 
position or viewpoi=
nt in their review, but must provide references to 
the strongest reference=
s that would disagree with them.

Reviews may cover any area of testing, in=
cluding ethics, methodology, 
education and training, law, or commercial is=
sues (such as outsourcing 
or certification). The editor and reviewers must=
 be convinced however 
that the topic or question is relevant, important, a=
nd is covered 
thoroughly, fairly, and in a way that makes sense of the top=
ic for the 
reader.

Much of the interesting work in testing was first done=
 in industry and 
presented in industry conferences or as technical reports=
 on private 
websites. References to these are encouraged, especially when =
a copy of 
the referenced report is still available to the general public.
=

Model journals for articles in this category:

=95 	ACM Computing Surveys
=
=95 	Psychological Bulletin
=95 	John Marshall Journal of Computer and Info=
rmation Law

CASE STUDIES (Peer Reviewed)

A case study provides an in-dept=
h description of an actual application 
or use of a model or theory, a tool=
, a technique, or a process. A good 
case study is typically rich in detail=
s, especially details that help 
us understand how and why the model (theor=
y, tool, technique, process) 
was (or was not) valuable and what we can do =
to make application 
easier, cheaper, or more successful. The details trigg=
er and support 
insights and help readers form hypotheses, rather than prov=
iding 
proofs. Case studies present editorial challenges. For example, we 
=
prefer to know the real names of companies and products, but ethical or 
le=
gal considerations sometimes make this impossible. Another example: 
we wil=
l err on the side of rejection if we suspect that a particular 
report is a=
 marketing document for a tool vendor or consultant. We 
encourage authors =
to disclose their backgrounds, biases, and potential 
conflicts of interest=
, but will not publish the sociopolitical rants 
that sometimes make up cas=
e study disclosures. We expect case study 
reports to be reflective. Nothin=
g goes perfectly; few things 
competently done fail completely. What could =
have been done differently 
and why? What conclusions should we be less or =
more confident in 
because of the details of the case? What hypotheses does=
 the case 
suggest for research, and what methodological suggestions does i=
t 
provide for executing the research?

A narrower type of case study is th=
e failure analysis. A failure 
analysis considers a failure that was caused=
 by a defect in the design 
or implementation of software. As with the long=
er case study, the 
article should provide details=97publicly-verifiable de=
tails if the 
product is identifiable=97and guidance to the reader as to th=
e underlying 
lessons to take away.

Ultimately, a key question for us will=
 be whether the case study's 
details will still be instructive for readers=
 ten years from now.

ARTICLE SETS (Peer Reviewed)

An article set includes=
 one or more original articles plus detailed, 
reviewed comments and critic=
isms of each article. This can be a way for 
authors who have competing vie=
ws or approaches to square off in a 
thorough, well-documented debate. We h=
ave seen some symposia, 
especially legal symposia, that have created such =
an effect, but we're 
willing to consider other structures.

We will not pu=
blish case studies that advocate the use of a particular 
tool, but we migh=
t publish a set of case studies that allow the reader 
to compare successes=
 of competing tools. The critical question is 
whether the set is likely to=
 give a careful reader insights into the 
class of tool (and the tool-assoc=
iated techniques).

METHODOLOGICAL REPORTS (Peer Reviewed)

Methodological =
reports describe new equipment and methods for 
conducting research. These =
are tutorials, from one scientist to 
another, explaining how to conduct a =
specific type of experiment or how 
to apply a specific type of equipment t=
o a type of experiment. This is 
not a place for vendor reports. Nor is it =
a place for re-explanations 
of matters that already appear in textbooks. M=
odels for such articles 
can be found in:

=95 	Behavior Research Methods, =
Instruments, & Computers

STATISTICAL METHODS & MODELS (Peer Reviewed)

JAS=
T will occasionally accept tutorial articles on the use of 
statistics or p=
robability models in software testing. The burden of 
persuasion is on the =
author to convince the editor that such an article 
fills an important gap =
in the knowledge of readers of this journal. 
Such a paper might establish =
context by citing examples of 
misunderstanding of the computation, theory =
or use of the statistic or 
probability model.

We have seen examples of su=
ch articles in:

=95 	ASQ Technometrics
=95 	Jurimetrics
=95 	Psychological=
 Bulletin

Authors are encouraged to submit a proposal for an article of th=
is type 
to the editor before submitting a manuscript. We suspect that 
rel=
atively few of these proposals will be accepted. For more author 
guidance,=
 see our Information For Authors.

POSITION PAPERS AND INTERVIEWS WITH FAMO=
US PEOPLE (NOT Peer Reviewed)

The Journal will sometimes accept position p=
apers, editorials, and 
interviews of notable people in the field. The Edit=
or may consult 
colleagues in the evaluation of such a submission, but the =
final 
decision is the Editor's alone. The Editor's primary question is 
wh=
ether the article is likely to be of interest to readers of the 
current is=
sue and of continuing interest to future readers. For 
example, an intervie=
w in which Richard Feynman explained how he 
designed instructional materia=
ls might be of interest for decades.

REQUIREMENTS FOR PUBLICATION

Submitt=
ed materials must follow the style and guidelines of the 
American Psycholo=
gical Association. (See http://www.apastyle.org ) A 
brief summary of the r=
eferencing style is available at 
http://webster.commnet.edu/apa/apa_index.=
htm

Submitted articles must be written in English and be in final or 
near=
-final form. Unless the editor has given prior permission to submit 
a roug=
h draft, rough drafts will be returned unreviewed.

Submitted materials mus=
t be original and unpublished. We will consider 
articles that describe mat=
erial originally presented at a conference, 
but the article must substanti=
ally extend the conference presentation. 
If a conference paper was publish=
ed, this must be disclosed at time of 
submission and the submitted article=
 must be so differently worded from 
the conference paper there is unquesti=
onably no infringement of the 
rights of the owner of copyright in the conf=
erence paper.

The person submitting an article must have the authority to =
publish it. 
For example, we cannot accept and publish an article that reve=
als trade 
secrets of the author's employer.

Finally, JAST has a zero-tole=
rance policy with regard to plagiarism. 
JAST will not knowingly publish a =
plagiarized article and it will 
reject without review, as a matter of poli=
cy, any submissions from 
authors who previously submitted a plagiarized ar=
ticle to JAST.
